1.passage:
Which is it to-day?" [MASK] asked, "morphine or cocaine?"

He raised his eyes languidly from the old black-letter volume which he had opened.

3.passage:
He raised his eyes languidly from the old black-letter volume which he had opened. "It is cocaine," [MASK] said, "a seven-per-cent. solution. Would you care to try it?"

"No, indeed," I answered, brusquely.

4.passage:
Would you care to try it?"

"No, indeed," [MASK] answered, brusquely. "My constitution has not got over the Afghan campaign yet.

9.passage:
But consider!" [MASK] said, earnestly. "Count the cost! Your brain may, as you say, be roused and excited, but it is a pathological and morbid process, which involves increased tissue-change and may at last leave a permanent weakness. You know, too, what a black reaction comes upon you. Surely the game is hardly worth the candle. Why should you, for a mere passing pleasure, risk the loss of those great powers with which you have been endowed? Remember that I speak not only as one comrade to another, but as a medical man to one for whose constitution he is to some extent answerable."

He did not seem offended.

10.passage:
On the contrary, he put his finger-tips together and leaned his elbows on the arms of his chair, like one who has a relish for conversation.

"My mind," [MASK] said, "rebels at stagnation. Give me problems, give me work, give me the most abstruse cryptogram or the most intricate analysis, and I am in my own proper atmosphere.

13.passage:
I said, raising my eyebrows.

"The only unofficial consulting detective," [MASK] answered. "I am the last and highest court of appeal in detection.

15.passage:
But you have yourself had some experience of my methods of work in the Jefferson Hope case."

"Yes, indeed," said [MASK], cordially. "I was never so struck by anything in my life.

18.passage:
I glanced over it," said [MASK]. "Honestly, I cannot congratulate you upon it. Detection is, or ought to be, an exact science, and should be treated in the same cold and unemotional manner. You have attempted to tinge it with romanticism, which produces much the same effect as if you worked a love-story or an elopement into the fifth proposition of Euclid."

"But the romance was there

20.passage:
," [MASK] remonstrated. "I could not tamper with the facts."

"Some facts should be suppressed, or at least a just sense of proportion should be observed in treating them.

29.passage:
[MASK] cried, laughing. "Yes, I have been guilty of several monographs. They are all upon technical subjects. Here, for example, is one  Upon the Distinction between the Ashes of the Various Tobaccoes.  In it I enumerate a hundred and forty forms of cigar-, cigarette-, and pipe-tobacco, with coloured plates illustrating the difference in the ash. It is a point which is continually turning up in criminal trials, and which is sometimes of supreme importance as a clue. If you can say definitely, for example, that some murder has been done by a man who was smoking an Indian lunkah, it obviously narrows your field of search. To the trained eye there is as much difference between the black ash of a Trichinopoly and the white fluff of bird s-eye as there is between a cabbage and a potato."

"You have an extraordinary genius for minuti ," I remarked.

30.passage:
To the trained eye there is as much difference between the black ash of a Trichinopoly and the white fluff of bird s-eye as there is between a cabbage and a potato."

"You have an extraordinary genius for minuti ," [MASK] remarked.

"I appreciate their importance.

32.passage:
But I weary you with my hobby."

"Not at all," [MASK] answered, earnestly. "It is of the greatest interest to me, especially since I have had the opportunity of observing your practical application of it.

36.passage:
For example, observation shows me that you have been to the Wigmore Street Post-Office this morning, but deduction lets me know that when there you dispatched a telegram."

"Right!" said [MASK] "Right on both points!

38.passage:
It was a sudden impulse upon my part, and I have mentioned it to no one."

"It is simplicity itself," [MASK] remarked, chuckling at my surprise, "so absurdly simple that an explanation is superfluous; and yet it may serve to define the limits of observation and of deduction. Observation tells me that you have a little reddish mould adhering to your instep.

42.passage:
Eliminate all other factors, and the one which remains must be the truth."

"In this case it certainly is so," [MASK] replied, after a little thought. "The thing, however, is, as you say, of the simplest.

45.passage:
Would you think me impertinent if I were to put your theories to a more severe test?"

"On the contrary," [MASK] answered, "it would prevent me from taking a second dose of cocaine. I should be delighted to look into any problem which you might submit to me."

"I have heard you say that it is difficult for a man to have any object in daily use without leaving the impress of his individuality upon it in such a way that a trained observer might read it.

48.passage:
There are hardly any data," [MASK] remarked. "The watch has been recently cleaned, which robs me of my most suggestive facts."

"You are right," I answered.

50.passage: You are right," [MASK] answered. "It was cleaned before being sent to me." In my heart I accused my companion of putting forward a most lame and impotent excuse to cover his failure.

52.passage:
Though unsatisfactory, my research has not been entirely barren," [MASK] observed, staring up at the ceiling with dreamy, lack-lustre eyes. "Subject to your correction, I should judge that the watch belonged to your elder brother, who inherited it from your father."

"That you gather, no doubt, from the H. W. upon the back?"

"Quite so.

55.passage:
It has, therefore, been in the hands of your eldest brother."

"Right, so far," said [MASK] "Anything else?"

"He was a man of untidy habits, very untidy and careless.

It is unkind, and, to speak plainly, has a touch of charlatanism in it."

He leaned forward in his chair with an expression of extraordinary concentration upon his clear-cut, hawklike features. "State your case," said [MASK], in brisk, business tones.

I felt that my position was an embarrassing one.

To my surprise, the young lady held up her gloved hand to detain me. "If your friend," [MASK] said, "would be good enough to stop, he might be of inestimable service to me."

I relapsed into my chair.

I relapsed into my chair.

"I have not yet described to you the most singular part.

she asked, with something appealing in her voice and expression.

I did not observe."

"I give you my word on that," she answered.

149.passage:
Rochester Row," said [MASK]. "Now Vincent Square. Now we come out on the Vauxhall Bridge Road. We are making for the Surrey side, apparently. Yes, I thought so. Now we are on the bridge. You can catch glimpses of the river."

We did indeed get a fleeting view of a stretch of the Thames with the lamps shining upon the broad, silent water; but our cab dashed on, and was soon involved in a labyrinth of streets upon the other side.

He sat down upon a low settee and blinked at us inquiringly with his weak, watery blue eyes.

I nodded to show my agreement.

203.passage:
My health is somewhat fragile," [MASK] remarked, as he led the way down the passage. "I am compelled to be a valetudinarian."

Our cab was awaiting us outside, and our programme was evidently prearranged, for the driver started off at once at a rapid pace.

I do not know what to make of it."

None," said [MASK]. "But I see the glint of a light in that little window beside the door."

Yes, do!" pleaded [MASK]. "I really do not feel equal to giving directions."

[MASK] cried, with an hysterical sob. "It does me good to see you. Oh, but I have been sorely tried this day!"

This is all an insoluble mystery to me," said I. "It grows darker instead of clearer."

278.passage:
We were a good sixty feet from the ground, and, look where I would, I could see no foothold, nor as much as a crevice in the brick-work.

"It is absolutely impossible," [MASK] answered.

"Without aid it is so.

279.passage:
It is absolutely impossible," I answered.

"Without aid it is so. But suppose you had a friend up here who lowered you this good stout rope which I see in the corner, securing one end of it to this great hook in the wall. Then, I think, if you were an active man, You might swarm up, wooden leg and all. You would depart, of course, in the same fashion, and your ally would draw up the rope, untie it from the hook, shut the window, snib it on the inside, and get away in the way that he originally came. As a minor point it may be noted," [MASK] continued, fingering the rope, "that our wooden-legged friend, though a fair climber, was not a professional sailor. His hands were far from horny.

281.passage:
My lens discloses more than one blood-mark, especially towards the end of the rope, from which I gather that he slipped down with such velocity that he took the skin off his hand."

"This is all very well," said [MASK], "but the thing becomes more unintelligible than ever. How about this mysterious ally?

How came he into the room?"

"Yes, the ally!" repeated [MASK], pensively. "There are features of interest about this ally.

285.passage:
I fancy that this ally breaks fresh ground in the annals of crime in this country, though parallel cases suggest themselves from India, and, if my memory serves me, from Senegambia."

Apply them, and it will be instructive to compare results."

How does all that fit into your theory?"

"Confirms it in every respect," said the fat detective, pompously. "House is full of Indian curiosities.

"That is all over," [MASK] answered. "It was nothing.

736.passage:
I got leave to bring it with me, thinking that it would interest you to be the first to see it."

"It would be of the greatest interest to me," [MASK] said. There was no eagerness in her voice, however.

737.passage:
It had struck her, doubtless, that it might seem ungracious upon her part to be indifferent to a prize which had cost so much to win.

"What a pretty box!" [MASK] said, stooping over it.

744.passage:
It was absolutely and completely empty.

"The treasure is lost," said [MASK], calmly.

As I listened to the words and realised what they meant, a great shadow seemed to pass from my soul.

746.passage: She looked at me with a quick, questioning smile. "Why do you say that?" [MASK] asked.

751.passage:
His face clouded over when I showed him the empty box.

"There goes the reward!" said [MASK], gloomily. "Where there is no money there is no pay.

762.passage:
If you had wished to throw the treasure into the Thames it would have been easier for you to have thrown box and all."

"Easier for me to throw, and easier for you to recover," [MASK] answered, with a shrewd, sidelong look. "The man that was clever enough to hunt me down is clever enough to pick an iron box from the bottom of a river.

769.passage:
You forget that we know nothing of all this," said [MASK] quietly. "We have not heard your story, and we cannot tell how far justice may originally have been on your side."

"Well, sir, you have been very fair-spoken to me, though I can see that I have you to thank that I have these bracelets upon my wrists.

808.passage:
He may have observed it, for there was a touch of defiance in his voice and manner as he proceeded.

"It was all very bad, no doubt," said [MASK]. "I should like to know how many fellows in my shoes would have refused a share of this loot when they knew that they would have their throats cut for their pains.

865.passage:
Ah, of course," said [MASK]. "I had not thought of that."

"Is there any other point which you would like to ask about?" asked the convict, affably.

866.passage:
I had not thought of that."

"Is there any other point which you would like to ask about?" asked [MASK], affably.

"I think not, thank you," my companion answered.

873.passage:
I ll take particular care that you don t club me with your wooden leg, whatever you may have done to the gentleman at the Andaman Isles."

"Well, and there is the end of our little drama," [MASK] remarked, after we had set some time smoking in silence. "I fear that it may be the last investigation in which I shall have the chance of studying your methods.

877.passage:
I really cannot congratulate you."

I was a little hurt. "Have you any reason to be dissatisfied with my choice?" [MASK] asked.

880.passage:
I should never marry myself, lest I bias my judgment."

"I trust," said [MASK], laughing, "that my judgment may survive the ordeal. But you look weary."

"Yes, the reaction is already upon me.

882.passage:
I shall be as limp as a rag for a week."

"Strange," said [MASK], "how terms of what in another man I should call laziness alternate with your fits of splendid energy and vigour."

"Yes," he answered, "there are in me the makings of a very fine loafer and also of a pretty spry sort of fellow.
